entry.title: PLM Tech Uncovered: SAP Integrated Product Development Update 11/2025
entry.content:
Welcome back to PLM Tech Uncovered! I‚Äôm excited to take you through the latest enhancements in SAP Integrated Product Development. There‚Äôs a lot to unpack, so let‚Äôs get started!

Requirements Management and Systems Modeling

Manage properties for a permission

You can now manage permissions at a property level within a requirement model. In the Properties panel of a requirement model, a new option Property Permissions is added to the Permissions tab. Use this option to manage access control for individual properties within a requirement model.

Manage permissions for a requirement

A new tab Permissions is added to the Properties panel displayed when you select a requirement. Through this tab, you can manage the permission levels of users and groups for a requirement within its requirement model. Previously, users can only edit permissions on the requirement models.

Authorization and permission enhancements

You can now apply selected permissions to all child requirements, throughout the entire requirement hierarchy. You can perform this action by using the Copy Permissions to All Children option. It is available in the Permissions tab in Properties panel for repositories (and its objects) and requirement models.

Specification Management 

Property data transfer between specifications 

Property data transfer saves time and improves accuracy by eliminating manual re-entry, ensuring consistency and reducing errors across related specifications. You can transfer individual properties or use property templates to update existing specifications in the Manage Specifications app.

Visualization

Execute script from Browse app

You can now run scripts for a visualization from the Browse app. You can perform this by using the Execute Script option available in the option (More) on a visualization card.

üîî  To stay informed until the next update you can: 

  • Subscribe to the What‚Äôs New Viewer on SAP Integrated Product Development Help Portal 
  • Join our LinkedIn group SAP Solutions for PLM
  • Visit us at www.sap.com/IPD  

üì£  Want to give feedback on SAP Integrated Product Development?
üé•  Watch this short video to see how, then send your feedback directly from the app‚Äîwe‚Äôd love to hear from you.

If the option to use a provider support user created in the Landscape Portal does not work, you could also use your user in provider tenant 100 with the role based on the template SAP_BR_APPL_SUP_ENG_DEV_SUP.  This user should also be able to log in via ADT.

entry.title: Re: Security roles in select source of supply
entry.content:
Hi,

In the Source of Supply popup, the icon highlighted in the screenshot is the personalization icon, which allows end users to add or remove columns (including the Price field). This personalization capability is controlled at user level and cannot be locked or disabled in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

  • SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúAdapt Filters / Adapt Columns‚Äù icon is part of standard Fiori table personalization.

  • In Public Cloud, SAP does not provide configuration options to:

    • Disable this icon,

    • Freeze the screen layout, or

    • Prevent users from re-adding a field that exists in the underlying data model.

As a result, even if you remove the Price field through UI adaptation or hide it initially, users can re-personalize the view and add it back, as long as the field is technically available.

If your security policy requires a full lock of table personalization, this would need SAP enhancement.
You can raise it via the SAP Influence Portal, as this option is not supported in current standard functionality.

  1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition
  2.  Register and accept the Terms of Use
  3.  Choose a session of your interest
  4. Create and submit your improvement request
  5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

Thank you,

Krithika

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA for Utilities 2023 Market Process Management...
entry.content:
Hi @jack_tie,

the product ‚ÄúMarket process management for utilities for SAP S/4HANA‚Äù (MPM) will be in maintenance until 31.12.2030, as already committed in the Release Availability Document. It is an add-on to SAP S/4HANA Utilities. Maintenance of current Release SAP S/4HANA MPM UTIL 2305 is extended to 31.12.2030 as well to fulfill the above general maintenance commitment. 

With regards to MPM, there are no plans for a follow up Release, meaning no release of MPM will be made available on SAP S/4HANA 2025. The Application Process Engine (APE), MCM-Adaptor and all other features in technical components APE and UCOM have been moved into the S/4HANA Utilities stack with S/4HANA 2025. They are now part of S/4HANA Utilities from that release onwards and underly standard maintenance commitment for that product.

We believe, that with the move of the major MPM components into the standard SAP S/4HANA Utilities product, our customers will have certainty on maintenance planning by SAP, and have even higher confidence in introducing the process framework. With the extension of maintenance on S/4HANA MPM UTIL 2305 to end of 2030, we provide more time to transition from IDXGC to APE and upgrade to S/4HANA 2025.

Also see 1745581 - Release strategy for the ABAP Add-On IDXGC - SAP for Me and 2708496 - Release strategy and Maintenance Information for the ABAP add-ons APE and UIAPE - SAP for Me

Best regards

Sebastian Schiefer

Head of Product Management Utilities Market Communication & Distributed Energy Resources
Industry Product Engineering
SAP SE

entry.title: Becoming a Data Architect: Your First Step in the Data Architecture Learning Journey
entry.content:
In an era where data drives innovation, strategy, and transformation, Data Architecture has become the cornerstone of enterprise success. To bridge the gap between technical expertise and strategic impact, SAP Data Architecture experts and the SIX learning team have collaborated to introduce the "Becoming a Data Architecture Course (Foundational)," the first stage in the "Becoming a Data Architect" program.  
 
This course empowers aspiring architects, data professionals, data solution experts, and Data enthusiasts to master the principles, paradigms, and frameworks that define modern enterprise data architecture. 
 
Overview of the Learning 
 
The Data Architecture course is structured as a learning pyramid, designed to build expertise layer by layer ‚Äî from foundational principles to strategic business impact. 
 
At its base lies Unit 1: Foundational Concepts, which anchors learners in the essential principles of modelling, metadata management, and architectural alignment. It serves as the bedrock upon which all modern data paradigms and governance strategies are built. You will understand the basic terminology and fundamentals of Data Architecture, including conceptual, logical, and physical data models, which ensure efficiency and scalability. Understand what metadata and semantic management are and how data architecture integrates with enterprise architecture frameworks such as Zachman and TOGAF. 
In the second unit (Unit 2: Modern Paradigms & Integration), we cover contemporary data architecture patterns, including Data Mesh, Data Fabric, Data Lake, and Data Lakehouse, and compare them based on different considerations. The unit also explores integration and pipeline approaches, such as ETL and ELT, and when to use each.  
In Unit 3: Governance, Security & Strategic Impact ‚Äì we cover details of establishing comprehensive data governance frameworks (including stewardship and data lineage) and integrate security and privacy controls to ensure compliance with relevant regulations and secure AI/ML use cases. As data ecosystems grow, governance and security become the bedrock of trust and compliance. This unit develops your ability to design, secure, and align enterprise data strategies. 
And finally, in Unit 4, Communicating Data Value: A great architect not only designs systems, but they also inspire transformation. This final unit reinforces the communication and leadership skills necessary to effect change. We talk about how you can communicate Architectural Value: Articulate the limitations of the current data landscape ("as-is") and present a compelling, business-focused narrative for the benefits of the proposed future-state ("to-be") architecture (quality, cost, scale).  
 
Who Should Take This Course
 
This course is designed for data professionals at every stage of their career who want to evolve from technical roles into strategic architectural leadership. Ideal participants include, but are not limited to:  
  1. Data Engineers and Modellers seeking to advance into architectural roles. 
  2. Solution and Enterprise Architects aiming to strengthen their data design and governance foundations. 
  3. Business Intelligence and Analytics professionals who need to understand how architecture underpins data-driven decision-making. 
  4. IT and Transformation leaders looking to align data systems with business outcomes. 
 
Why take this course? 
Because modern organisations need architects who understand both technology and business value. By mastering foundational architecture principles, you‚Äôll: 
  1. Improve data discoverability, quality, and governance. 
  2. Learn how to connect data architecture to enterprise goals. 
  3. Gain the credibility to influence strategic data decisions. 
  4. Prepare for the SAP Certified Data Architect* specialization that is planned for launch in 2026 
 
How to Start Your Course
You can get started today without any prerequisites via the learning.sap.com: Becoming an SAP Data Architect (Foundational)  
But this is just a starting point - Becoming a Data Architect is not just about mastering tools or technologies‚Äîit‚Äôs about developing architectural thinking. This Foundational Concepts course sets the stage for you to evolve into a strategic leader who can design, communicate, and drive data transformation in any organization.  
 
In 2026, we plan to launch the Data Architecture Advanced course and Data Architect Certification (C_BDCDA), which will provide you with a comprehensive path to becoming a skilled Data Architect.  
 
Ready to begin? 
Visit SAP Learning and enrol in the Becoming an SAP Data Architect ‚Äì Foundational course today!

entry.title: Extend the Document Stroe of Analytical Cell Comments by Developer Extensibility
entry.content:
This blog explains how to extend the Document Store by developer extensibility in Embedded Steampunk of S4 Public Cloud. The following contents are covered:

  • Introduction of cell commenting feature and Document Store. 
  • Prerequisites of Document Store developer extensibility„ÄÇ
  • Extend Document Store by developer extensibility.

1. Introduction of cell commenting feature and Document Store 

In some Review Booklet and Multidimensional Analysis  (MDA) Apps, users might see a ‚Äúcomment‚Äù button in the side panel and then users can add comments on a data cell of the grid through the comments side panel. This feature is called Cell Commenting, as shown in the following figure: 

 

To enable the Cell Commenting feature the analytical cube and query must be enabled with Document Store which stores the context of the cell, including the fixed filters in the filter bar, the dynamic filters and the selected dimensions on row and column.

Document Store consists of two artifacts:

  • Document Store Table: a database table to store the cell context.
  • Document Store CDS View: a special category of CDS view which selects from the Document Store Table and has annotation @analytics.dataCategory: #DOCSTORE.

The fields in the Document Store are pure technical fields related to the dimensions of the cube. A dimension in cube can have maximum 6 related fields as following: 

Naming RuleMeaningData Type
TRA_* Transient Characteristic The same data type as the dimension 

SVA_* 

Single Character Variable 

Char(1) 

SVH_* 

Single Variable for Hierarchy 

Char(1) 

HIO_* 

Hierarchy Object 

Char(30) 

HNM_* 

Hierarchy Name 

Char(30) 

HNO_* 

Hierarchy Node Object 

Char(23) 

*: could be the same field name in cube, for example TRA_COMPANYCODE, or a number. The maximum length of the field name in the Document Store is 18, so when the length of cube field name plus the prefix(TRA_, SVA_, ...) exceeds the maximum, a number should be used instead, for example TRA_00001, TRA_00002. Just make sure the field name is unique in the table.

The enablement of Document Store for analytical cube and query include:

  • The Document Store is created for the analical cube view.
  • The analytical cube view is associated to the Document Store CDS view and the association is exposed.
  • The analytical query view contain the Document Store association exposed in cube view. 

For SAP delivered Review Booklets or Multidimensional Analysis applications, if the commenting feature is enabled the above steps have already been done. 

 

2. Prerequisites of Document Store Developer Extensibility 

When a document store enabled cube is extended with a new dimension field by developer extensibility or key user extensibility, the document store will not be extended automatically. In this situation, this new extended field cannot support Cell Commenting. It means if the new dimension is used in the report layout(added in the row or column) or the filter, an error will be raised when you try to create a comment on the cell. Nevertheless, if the new dimension is not used in the report layout or filter, the cell commenting is not impacted, and you can still add comments for the data cells. 

Please be known that if you extend the cube and query with a measure type field, extension is not needed on the Document Store. Only new added dimension fields need the extension in Document Store accordingly. 

There are some prerequisites to extend the Document Store by developer extensibility: 

  • The Document Table and Document CDS View must be C0 released for ‚ÄòUse in Cloud Development‚Äô.
  • The Document Table should have some extensibility annotations which start with ‚Äò@AbapCatalog.enhancement‚Äô. 
  • The Document CDS View should also have the extensibility annotations which start with ‚Äò@AbapCatalog.extensibility‚Äô. 

If the prerequisites are not met, please ask SAP to enable the C0 release. 

 

3. Extend the Document Store by Developoer Extensibility

When you have extended the cube with a dimension field, either by developer extensibility or key user extensibility, and want to extend the document store, please follow the steps below. 

3.1 Find Dimention Type

  • Open "Relation Explorer" in‚ÄØABAP Developer Tool (in the cube right click and select 'Show In‚Üí Relation Explorer) 
  • Check the details on the new-added dimension on the right side, please pay attention to the text in the ‚Äú[ ]‚Äù, it means which kind of dimension it is.  

Ralation Explorer

[Hier] means the dimension has a foreign key association and the association target has hierarchy assocation.

For every new extended dimension field, two types of fields need to be added in the Document‚ÄØCDS‚ÄØView. They are denoted by: 

                  @analytics.document.type: #TRA  

                  @analytics.document.type: #SVA

If the extended dimension has [Hier], four additional fields need to be added in the Document Store CDS View. They are denoted by:

                  @analytics.document.type: #SVH 

                  @analytics.document.type: #HIO  

                  @analytics.document.type: #HNM 

                  @analytics.document.type: #HNO  

As said above, the TRA field should have the same data type as the field in the cube. For key user extensibility case, you can find the data type of new extended dimension in the following way: open the cube view in ADT, and put the cursor on the name of the cube, then press F2 you will see the information of the cube, as the following figure shows:

3.2 Extend the Document Store Table

 Assume a new dimension field PostingLevel_2 has been extended in the cube view. It has a foreign key association‚ÄØI_CnsldtnPostingLevel which has a hierarchy association _PostgLevelHierNode, then 6 fields need to be extended in the document store table and document store‚ÄØCDS‚ÄØview respectively. 

To extend the Document Table, in the ADT of your Embedded Steampunk development system, right click the package, select New -> Other ABAP Repository Object->Structure. Give the name and description, then you can create the structure (which is actually a structure extension). Assume the Document Store table name is ‚Äòtest_doc_store_tab‚Äô, then a new structure extension would be created with the name  ‚Äòtest_doc_store_ext‚Äù as the following code: 

extend type test_doc_store_tab with test_doc_store_ext { 
  tra_00062_dcu‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ : fc_plevl; 
  sva_00062_dcu‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ : abap.char(1); 
  svh_00062_dcu‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ : abap.char(1); 
  hnm_00062_dcu‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ : abap.char(30); 
  hno_00062_dcu‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ: abap.char(32); 
  hio_00062_dcu‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ: abap.char(30); 
}

You can also use template ‚ÄòappendStructure‚Äô to create the skeleton of the code. 

A correct suffix should be added for the fields according to the definition of annotation @AbapCatalog.enhancement.fieldSuffix  in the Document Store Table. Here ‚Äòdcu‚Äô is used as an example. You should also add prefix before the name for customer development as normal. 

As the length of field name ‚ÄúPostingLevel_2‚Äù is more than 13, a unique number should be used instead, normally we are using the existing max number plus 1 to get the number.‚ÄØIf the field name is short than 13, please use the field name directly, for example sva_glaccount. 

For field TRA_* the data type should be the same as the field in the cube, so here TRA_00062 uses fc_plevl. 

3.3 Extend the Document Store CDS View

Similarly, 6 fields should be added in the Document‚ÄØCDS‚ÄØView. In ADT, right click the package, select New-> Other ABAP Repository Object ->Data Definition. Write the code as following: 

extend view entity I_CDS_TST_SO_HEADER_CUBEDST with { 
  @analytics.document:{ type: #TRA , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.tra_0062_dcu as tra_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #SVA , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.sva_0062_dcu as sva_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #SVH , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.svh_0062_dcu as svh_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HNM , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.hnm_0062_dcu as hnm_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HNO , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.hno_0062_dcu as hno_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HIO , reference: 'PostingLevel_2 ' } 
  Persistence.hio_0062_dcu as hio_0062_dcu, 
}

You can also use the template ‚ÄòextendViewEntity‚Äô to create the skeleton of the code.  

A correct suffix should be added for the fields according to the definition of annotation @ @AbapCatalog.extensibility.elementSuffix  in the Document Store CDS View. Here ‚Äòdcu‚Äô is used as an example. You should also add prefix before the name for customer development as normal. 

Here ‚ÄòPersistence‚Äô is the data source of the Document Store CDS View, that is the Document Store Table. Refer to the following example of a Document Store CDS View: 

                       

In the above example, 6 fields are added. For the simple case without hierarchy association, only two fields(TRA_* and SVA_*) are needed.

After the above stpes you will finish the developer extension of Document Store. You can verify the extesion by checking the information of the Document CDS View (press F2 on the view name). Now the users are able to add comments for the new extended dimension.

 

Further Links and Resources

 SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionSAP S/4HANA/SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
Review Bookletslink to help.sap.comlink to help.sap.com
Multidimensional Analysislink to help.sap.comlink to help.sap.com
Cell Commentinglink to help.sap.comlink to help.sap.com

entry.title: Understanding how to set up E-Verify in SuccessFactors in Onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss how E-Verify works with SuccessFactors onboarding and some of the common questions raised by customers and consultants.  We will discuss three main scenarios.  This article is aimed at non USA consultants who may not be familiar with the I9 and compliance process.  We will cover two main processes

  • Customer wanting to set up E-Verify for the first time with SuccessFactors Onboarding
  • Customer migrating from Onboarding 1.0 to 2.0

 

Background

E-Verify is a free, web-based system that allows employers to confirm the employment eligibility of their new hires in the United States. It compares information from the employee's I-9 to records from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Social Security Administration (SSA) to verify the employee is authorized to work. While it's voluntary for most employers, some are required to use it by state law or federal contracts.

During the hiring process a candidate completes ‚ÄòSection 1‚Äô of the I9 during the onboarding process.  This is then validated by the ‚Äòcompany representative‚Äô they are being employed by, this is known as ‚Äòcompleting section 2‚Äô.  Once this is completed the standard integration from SuccessFactors onboarding creates an E-Verify case and checks the data.  Depending on the data, it may be automatically approved/closed or further action may by the company representative.

You can set up I9s without E-Verify as they require two separate configurations

You can set up a test E-Verify account in SuccessFactors onboarding to see how the end to end process works.

Customer who are moving to SuccessFactors onboarding may already have an E-Verify account so we will look at how they might be impacted.

Customer wanting to set up E-Verify for the first time with SuccessFactors Onboarding

If the customer has not used Onboarding 1.0 or the have their own E-Verify account they will need to request a new MOU from the SAP E-Verify team.   This is detailed in this KBA

2421435 - How to create an Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) for E-Verify [Compliance] - Onboarding module - SAP for Me

They can‚Äôt use the old MOU in SuccessFactors onboarding as this MOU is set up with a different Employing Agent.  SAP are they Designated Agent for our customers.  It is important that when you request the new MOU organization don‚Äôt close down the old MOU until they are happy that everyone has been processed as once an MOU has been closed it can‚Äôt re-opened easily.

Finally, customers need to email the SAP E-Verify team to request an MOU and you  can‚Äôt do this via webservices.  Once an MOU has been provided this will need to be added to the compliance centre as shown below.

You will still need to define the account type.

Two rules need to be configured.

The ‚ÄòE-Verify enablement rule‚Äô needs to be created.  This rule controls who needs to complete E-Verify, this can be done for all hires in USA, or you can trigger E-Verify for certain legal entities.

Finally, the rule for ‚ÄòCorporate representative‚Äô will control who will need to complete any E-Verify actions generated.  It can be the same groups as section 2 or different groups.  Either way you will need to ensure the people have the correct E-Verify permission in RBP.

 

 

Customer migrating from Onboarding 1.0 to 2.0

If you are already using E-Verify in 1.0 then you can use the same MOU.  If you are not using E-Verify in 1.0 but would like to do so then you would need to request an MOU as described above.

When you use E-Verify with SuccessFactors onboarding whether 1.0 or 2.0 you do not get a username/password to log into E-Verify directly.  All interactions with E-Verify are done via SuccessFactors, including manually creating an E-Verify case.

Hopefully this article will answer some of the questions around setting up E-Verify in SuccessFactors,

entry.title: KSeF 2.0 Test Environment: Automate the Retrieval of Electronic Documents with the Cloud Edition
entry.content:
You are setting up your system for the new invoice format required for KSeF 2.0 and want to understand how to test automated retrieval of invoices from the tax authority portal to achieve end-to-end processing of electronic documents.

With the Schedule Jobs app in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition, you can create one job that automates the retrieval of supplier or self-billing invoices from the tax authority portal to your business system (for example, SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP) . This makes the following activities in your business system obsolete:

  • Processing eDocument Inbound Messages
  • Processing Incoming Messages with Additional Filters
  • Processing eDocument Status Message
  • Processing Status Messages for Multiple eDocuments

Meaning, you no longer use the eDocument Inbound Message Handler for these activities. Instead, you use Schedule Jobs app.

How it works?

  1. You schedule a job in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. The system automatically creates a request based on the job configuration.
  2. The cloud edition takes invoice data from Krajowy System e-Faktur (KSeF), a platform from the Polish tax authority used to exchange electronic invoices.
  3. The cloud edition decrypts retrieved invoices, creates visualization as PDF files and pushes to the destination business system selected for the job.
  4. The business system creates the electronic document and updates its status. The XML (FA(3)) and PDF files are available in the history of the electronic document. Here you can also check if any duplicate documents were retrieved.
    Note: To see the attached XML (FA(3)) and PDF files, select the electronic document and open Attachments in the Manage Electronic Documents app, or History in the eDocument Cockpit transaction.

Test Use Cases

In this blog, I share details on two key scenarios for downloading invoices that you might want to apply with the Schedule Jobs app:

  • Downloading purchase invoices
  • Downloading sales invoices for self-billing

Prerequisites

You have already performed the general integration settings for test environment as described in this blog: KSeF 2.0 Test Environment: Setup and Integrate Your System with the Cloud Edition.

Now, you can test configuring automated jobs for retrieving your invoices from tax authority portal using the Schedule Jobs app.  To access the app, go to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition launchpad in your associated SAP BTP subaccount. See Scheduling Jobs.

Configuration is guided through a step-by-step wizard:

  1. Define the general settings for the job, by selecting:
    • Process Flow:  Retrieving Documents for E-Invoices Through KseF (PL)
    • Identification Number: Select the NIP number you have set for communication type E-Invoices Through KSeF 2.0 (PL). See Managing Communication Settings.

  2. Configure additional properties required by KSeF 2.0 to provide the data to the cloud edition. This is where you pay attention to achieve the scenarios.

    Scenario 1: You want to schedule job to retrieve invoices where your company is the buyer.

    • subjectType: Subject2 (Buyer)
    • dateType: Issue (Use for KSeF 2.0 test environment).
      Note: Later, for production, it‚Äôs recommended to use PermanentStorage (based on archival date) to avoid missing invoices.
    • Buyer Identifier Type: Select Nip or VatUe. 
    • Buyer Identifier Value: Enter the identification number of your company according to the type you selected.

    Scenario 2: You want to schedule a job to retrieve invoices issued under self-invoicing mode where your company acts as the seller.

    • subjectType: Subject1 (Seller)
    • dateType: Issue (Use for KSeF 2.0 test environment).
      Note: Later, for production, it‚Äôs recommended to use PermanentStorage (based on archival date) to avoid missing invoices.
    • sellerNIP: Your company NIP number
    • isSelfInvoicing: Select the checkbox

  3. Define the frequency of your job. Example configuration can be:
    • Every 2 hours ‚Äì the cloud edition will send a request for retrieving the invoices every 2 hours and will get the invoices created in between.
    • One-Time ‚Äì you can use this to get the invoices for a certain period in the past, for example, the period before the first run of your recurring job.

  4. Select the destination you created for the business system in which you want to receive the documents. See Setting Up Connectivity.

Once you save your configuration, you can monitor the results of your job runs ‚Äì time details, status, results, troubleshooting steps. See Viewing Results of a Job Run.

For more information on KSeF 2.0 related features covered by SAP, you can access the Regulatory Change Manager for Mandatory e-Invoicing through KSeF in Poland.

entry.title: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Charan Ravikumar and Maria Kondratyeva

 

Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and Joule agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

However, we recognize that the partner landscape, with its mix of TDD, PAYG, and subscription accounts, introduces unique complexities. Many of you have asked the essential question: "How do we, as partners, get Joule Studio set up correctly in our environments?"

This guide is built specifically for you. It synthesizes insights from our support channels and direct partner feedback to address your most common challenges, such as multi-global account integrations and navigating the new SAP Build licensing in TDD environments. Whether you're starting fresh or integrating existing services, this post outlines everything you need to know to get started efficiently and cost-effectively.

Let's get started!

Critical Prerequisites: Licensing & Plans

Before diving into the setup flows, let's clarify three critical concepts that are often sources of confusion for partners. Getting these right from the start will save you significant time and effort.

The "New" SAP Build Plan (build-default)

Many partners have existing SAP Build entitlements on a legacy "standard" plan. To use Joule Studio, you must use the build-default plan, specifically for SAP Build Process Automation.

  • Critical Action: Do NOT order a new, separate SAP Build subscription! In your existing Partner TDD Global Account (under a PAYG model), the entitlement for the new plan is already available.
    • You simply need to navigate to the Service Marketplace in your BTP cockpit and activate the SAP Build Process Automation service, ensuring you select the build-default plan during setup.
  • Note: Ordering a new subscription instead of activating the existing entitlement often leads to selecting the wrong plan and creates unnecessary account complexity.
  • TDD Licensing Options:
    • License the Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP for cloud test, demo, and development (SKU 8009282). This grants you access to free "Fair Use Limits" for SAP Build (Recommended)
    • Alternative (Subscription): A subscription-based SAP Build TDD developer license (SKU 8019951) is also available, but it does not include the Fair Use Limits.
  • What is Fair Use Limits (FUL): The Fair Use Limit where the partner is provided an entitled specified threshold amount of TDD services free of charge per billing cycle. It‚Äôs designed to support development without unexpected costs.
    • Please refer to this link for more details on FUL - https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/assets/products/tech_plat/dgl/30/23/SAP1223023.html

  Joule Entitlement

    • Joule for Consultant and Joule for Developers are different licenses and not connected with Joule Studio license and its activation.
  • Cost for Custom Skills: There is no additional cost or AI Unit consumption for the orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills built with Joule Studio's current features.
    • However, the underlying services your skill uses (e.g., SAP Build Process Automation) will still follow their standard commercial models (e.g., consumption against your Fair Use Limits).

The Multi-Global Account Scenario

It is very common for partners to have their Joule entitlement in a TDD subscription based global account and their SAP Build entitlement in a separate TDD PAYG global account. This is a supported scenario.

  • The Golden Thread: The key to making this work is to ensure that both global accounts are federated under the same SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS). This single identity provider is what allows the two systems to trust each other and integrate seamlessly.
  • To run Joule Booster or Joule Formation (see table below), select the 2 global accounts you have.

Understanding Your Integration Flow: Starting Points and Required Steps

This table outlines the five primary scenarios for integrating SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA in the future text) capabilities into the Joule Studio environment.  Identify which flow best matches your current setup, whether you‚Äôre starting fresh or have existing SBPA or Joule subscriptions. This will immediately provide you with the exact action steps and critical notes required for a successful connection.

 

Starting Point

Key Action Steps

The partner is setting up both Joule and SBPA from scratch. 

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect Joule and SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has Joule (Booster provisioned) and now links the existing SBPA (it must be a build-default plan) for Joule Studio.

  1. Verify SBPA Prerequisites: Ensure SBPA entitlement is on the build-default plan (standard plan is not compatible).
  2. Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  3. Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  4. Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    1. Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    2. Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    3. Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    4. Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  5. Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  6. Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  7. Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    1. joule_extensibility
    2. end_user 

The partner has an existing SBPA (on the correct build-default plan) and now wants to add Joule.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above for Joule. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect the new Joule to the existing SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has both services (on the correct plan); they just need to be linked for Joule Studio.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The partner has both, but SBPA is on the standard plan (requires an upgrade).

  • Upgrade SBPA to the correct plan (build-default).
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

FAQ & Common Pitfalls for Partners

Q1: I don't see the build-default plan for SAP Build in my TDD account. How do I get it?   Do not order a new paid subscription. Ensure you have the correct TDD account with BTP PAYG license. Then, go to your BTP Cockpit -> Service Marketplace. Find "SAP Build Process Automation" and create a new instance/subscription, making sure to select the build-default plan.

Q2: My Joule and SAP Build are in different Global Accounts. Is that a problem?  No, this is a common and supported partner scenario. The absolute requirement is that both global accounts' subaccounts use the same Cloud Identity Service (IAS) tenant for authentication.

Q3: I ran the booster, but Joule Studio doesn't appear, or I get an error when deploying. What's wrong? This is almost always one of three issues:

  1. Mismatched Identity Services: Your Joule and SBPA subaccounts are pointing to different IAS tenants.
  2. Incorrect SBPA Plan: You are still on the "standard" plan instead of "build-default".
  3. Incorrect Joule SKU: Make sure you have a correct Joule license under Joule service TDD SKU (8018168) at no cost. To be on the safe side, please contact with your account manager, making sure you have right SKU enabled.
  4. Missing Role Collections: Your user is missing the joule_extensibility and end_user roles in the Joule subaccount, or the necessary developer roles in the SBPA subaccount.

Q4: I followed the steps, but deployment still fails with an IdP error: This points to a deeper trust configuration issue. Verify the trust settings between your BTP subaccounts and the IAS tenant. Ensure the Integration with Joule Formation status is Ready. If the issue persists, we recommend logging a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Q5: I am experiencing an ongoing issue and require further assistance. How may I contact you? Please submit a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Helpful Resources for Setup and Activation 

  • How to get started with Joule Studio
  • Provisioning Joule Studio 
  • Enabling Joule Studio for existing customers 
  • Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Reference Architecture for Joule Studio 
  • Activate Joule Studio in 5 Simple Steps

entry.title: Re: Delete FD32 Customer Credit limits
entry.content:
When you delete limits in FD32, you are working with the old credit management tables (KNKK). In S/4HANA, Sales orders no longer check KNKK. They use the new credit management engine (FSCM Credit Management) which is integrated with the Business Partner (BP) master data and Credit Control Areas. That is why in FI (FB70), no warning appears, because FI still looks at KNKK (classic). In SD (Sales Order), warnings appear, because SD checks FSCM credit exposure, not KNKK. So even though you deleted the limits in FD32, the FSCM credit master data (BP ‚Üí Credit Segment) still exists and is being evaluated.

If you don‚Äôt want credit checks for COD customers, you have a few options:

Go to BP transaction ‚Üí Role: UKM000 ‚Äì Credit Management. In the Credit Segment Data, either remove the credit limit, and set the Check Rule or Risk Category so that no credit check is performed. Alternatively, assign a special Risk Category (e.g., ‚ÄúCOD‚Äù) that is excluded from credit checks in customizing.

In OVA8, you can configure that for certain combinations (e.g., Sales Area + Risk Category + Credit Control Area), no credit check is triggered. Assign COD customers to this special category.

For COD customers, assign payment terms that are excluded from credit checks. In customizing, you can set rules so that orders with COD terms bypass credit management.

entry.title: Re: Delivery Note/Package Query
entry.content:
Hello,

Here is the correct query:

SELECT T0."DocNum", T1."ItemCode", SUM(T1."Quantity") AS "DelQty", A1."Quantity" AS "PackQty"
FROM ODLN T0
INNER JOIN DLN1 T1 ON T0."DocEntry" = T1."DocEntry"
LEFT JOIN
(SELECT T2."DocEntry", T2."ItemCode", SUM(T2."Quantity") AS "Quantity" FROM DLN8 T2 GROUP BY T2."DocEntry", T2."Itemcode") AS A1 ON T1."DocEntry" = A1."DocEntry" AND T1."ItemCode" = A1."ItemCode"
WHERE T0."DocNum" = '15079'
GROUP BY T0."DocNum", T1."ItemCode", A1."Quantity"
HAVING SUM(T1."Quantity") <> ISNULL(A1."Quantity",0)

entry.title: Comment SAP MM peut transformer le processus d‚Äôachats dans une entreprise
entry.content:
Le module SAP MM (Materials Management) est l‚Äôun des piliers des syst√®mes SAP pour la gestion des achats et des stocks. Une bonne utilisation de SAP MM peut r√©volutionner le processus d‚Äôapprovisionnement, en le rendant plus rapide, plus pr√©cis et plus efficace.

 Automatisation des achats SAP MM permet de g√©n√©rer automatiquement les demandes d‚Äôachat, les commandes

fournisseurs et les bons de r√©ception, en r√©duisant les erreurs humaines et en acc√©l√©rant le cycle P2P (Procure-to-Pay).

Meilleure gestion des fournisseurs

Le module centralise toutes les informations sur les fournisseurs : donn√©es de contact, conditions d‚Äôachat, historique de commandes, performances, etc. Cela facilite la s√©lection des meilleurs fournisseurs et le suivi des KPI.

Optimisation des stocks

SAP MM permet de suivre en temps r√©el les stocks disponibles, les mouvements de mat√©riel, et les niveaux de r√©approvisionnement. Cela r√©duit les ruptures de stock et les surstocks, am√©liorant la gestion du capital.

 Int√©gration avec les autres modules SAP

Gr√¢ce √† l‚Äôint√©gration avec SAP FI (finance) et SAP SD (ventes), SAP MM garantit que toutes les transactions d‚Äôachats ont un impact direct sur la comptabilit√© et la cha√Æne logistique. Cela offre une visibilit√© compl√®te et un contr√¥le pr√©cis des co√ªts.

Analyses et reporting avanc√©s

SAP MM fournit des rapports d√©taill√©s et des tableaux de bord pour suivre les performances des achats, analyser les √©carts de prix et anticiper les besoins futurs. Les d√©cisions deviennent plus rapides et bas√©es sur des donn√©es fiables.

En adoptant SAP MM, une entreprise peut transformer son processus d‚Äôapprovisionnement :plus de rapidit√© et d‚Äôefficacit√©,

  • moins d‚Äôerreurs,

  • meilleure visibilit√© sur les stocks et les fournisseurs,

  • d√©cisions bas√©es sur des donn√©es pr√©cises.

SAP MM n‚Äôest pas seulement un outil informatique, c‚Äôest un v√©ritable levier strat√©gique pour la performance des achats.

SAP ERP Cloud SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement

entry.title: Re: The post date of Returns Delivery can't be decided
entry.content:
The posting date of the journal entry is not taken directly from the Actual Goods Movement Date you enter in the returns delivery. Instead, the system uses the Release Date of the inspection document (the day you actually complete and release the inspection) as the posting date. That is why

  • You entered goods movement date = 2025‚Äë11‚Äë20.
  • You entered inspection date = 2025‚Äë11‚Äë20.
  • But the inspection was only released on 2025‚Äë12‚Äë04.
  • The system posts the accounting document with posting date = 2025‚Äë12‚Äë04.

This is by design in Public Cloud. The financial posting is tied to the release of the inspection lot, not the physical goods movement date you type in.

entry.title: CX_SADL_DUMP_APPL_MODEL_ERROR while sending GET Request to ODATA v4 with /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I am trying to create ODATA V4 as mentioned in SAP Note 2485370, So I created a custom entity in Eclipse and also a Class with below method implemented from interface /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC. 

@EndUserText.label: 'ZSAMPLE_SERVICE'
@ObjectModel.query.implementedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_SAMPLE_SERVICE'
define custom entity ZSAMPLE_SERVICE
{
   key component_material : abap.char(40);
       fg_material  : abap.char(40);
       fg_material_descr : abap.char(40);
  
}

And Class as below

CLASS ZCL_SAMPLE_SERVICE DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  inheriting from /iwbep/cx_gateway
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    INTERFACES /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC.
  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.



CLASS ZCL_SAMPLE_SERVICE IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~CREATE_ENTITY.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~CREATE_REFERENCE.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~DELETE_ENTITY.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~EXECUTE_ACTION.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~EXECUTE_FUNCTION.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~READ_ENTITY.

    DATA: TS_DATA TYPE zsample_service.
    TS_DATA-COMPONENT_MATERIAL = '12333333'.
    TS_DATA-FG_MATERIAL = '321'.
    TS_DATA-FG_MATERIAL_DESCR = 'This is material description'.


    IO_RESPONSE->SET_BUSI_DATA( TS_DATA ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~READ_ENTITY_LIST.
    DATA: TS_DATA TYPE zsample_service,
          TT_DATA TYPE TABLE OF zsample_service.
    TS_DATA-COMPONENT_MATERIAL = '12333333'.
    TS_DATA-FG_MATERIAL = '321'.
    TS_DATA-FG_MATERIAL_DESCR = 'This is material description'.
    APPEND TS_DATA TO TT_DATA.
    IO_RESPONSE->SET_BUSI_DATA( TT_DATA[] ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD /IWBEP/IF_V4_DP_BASIC~READ_REF_TARGET_KEY_DATA.

  ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: Re: Crystal reports is asking for the database login cred...
entry.content:
Hi,

The problem might be that your report is using ODBC or OLEDB connection and there is no such driver installed on your user machine, so you need to install these on your clients machine :

- SQL Native client 12

- SQL Server odbc driver 17 or 18

- SQL Server ole db driver 17 or 18

Regards

entry.title: The Power of UI Flexibility in SAP Project and Resource Management
entry.content:
Introduction

In today‚Äôs fast-moving projects, waiting for a development cycle to adjust a field, add a custom section, or visualize data from another system can slow down productivity.
That‚Äôs where UI Flexibility in SPRM Project Management comes in.

UI Flexibility allows key users ‚Äî not just developers ‚Äî to adapt and extend their applications without changing the source code. With just a few clicks, you can:

  • Add or reorder sections.
  • Embed external web pages or dashboards.
  • Forward live data from SPRM Project Management into external tools.

Its flexibility designed for business agility.

 

What UI Flexibility Enables

With UI Flexibility, key users can:

  • Create custom sections in the existing application layout.
  • Embed external content, such as web pages, apps, or analytics dashboards.
  • Propagate data from SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT to embedded content via URL parameters.
  • Leverage Public APIs to exchange information between the host app and embedded systems.

[Screenshot ‚Äì Example of a custom embedded section with an planning calendar]

You can extend your SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT workspace to include the tools and data you use daily.

 

Architecture Overview

UI Flexibility is built on top of the UFlex service and integrates directly with the SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT application framework.
It ensures all extensions stay secure, modular, and maintainable.

Architecture Layers

Layer

Description

SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT Application

Provides the core logic and standard UI containers.

UI Flexibility Layer

Allows runtime configuration of new sections and embedded content.

Embedded Content Layer

Hosts external pages or applications within secure iframes.

Public API Layer

Enables controlled, secure data exchange between SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT and custom apps.

 

[Diagram ‚Äì UI Flexibility and Embedded Content Architecture]

 

Embedding External Content

UI Flexibility supports embedding external web pages or applications directly within SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT screens.
Below there are examples for possible implementations:

  • Project dashboards
  • Reporting apps
  • Custom micro-frontends
  • Process documentation or help content

Each embedded component runs independently. This ensures that even if one service experiences issues, the rest of your application remains stable.

[Screenshot ‚Äì Embedded external team calendar example]

Important Note: The embedded app is isolated from SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT. Any data exchange should occur through defined URL parameters or Public APIs only.

 

Data Propagation and Public API Access

How it Works

When configuring an embedded section, you can select which SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT data should be forwarded to the embedded content via the URL i.e. test.com/Projects/{Uuid}/{CollaborationOwner}
This enables the external page to operate in context ‚Äî for example, knowing which project or object the user is viewing.

Example Uses:

  • Display custom KPIs using project data.
  • Trigger external workflows when a user opens a section.
  • Write back updates to analytics tools using the Public API.

Tip: Combine URL-based data propagation with Public API calls for dynamic, two-way integrations.

 

Technical Insight: Interaction Model

Although UI Flexibility gives freedom to embed and integrate, it respects browser and framework boundaries.

Key facts:

  • Embedded apps are rendered in iframes.
  • Browsers restrict direct event sharing between the host and iframe. This is done via the sandbox flags which can also be removed, but this is not recommended.
  • Edit or Save events in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT are not automatically communicated to the embedded app.
  • Each embedded component should manage its own logic and data lifecycle.

Hint: Design embedded apps as standalone micro-applications that can run independently, even outside the host context.

 

 Example Setup: Creating an Embedded Section


Here‚Äôs how to configure your first embedded section using UI Flexibility.

  1. Go to UI Flexibility Settings in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT.
  2. Select ‚ÄúAdd New Section‚Äù.
  3. Choose Embedded Content as the section type.
  4. Enter the URL of your external web page or app.
  5. (Optional) Select which SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT fields to pass as URL parameters.
  6. Save and refresh ‚Äî your new embedded section appears instantly.

[Screenshot ‚Äì UI Flexibility setup]

Result: The embedded content behaves as a seamless part of your interface, while staying fully isolated and easy to maintain.

 

What You Can Achieve

Here‚Äôs what teams across projects are already doing with UI Flexibility:

  • Embedding live dashboards that update in real time.
  • Integrating specialized reporting tools.
  • Launching external workflow systems from within SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT.
  • Displaying custom KPIs per project, using propagated data.

 

Visual Demo Plan

For upcoming internal showcases, we‚Äôll include the following visuals:

  1. UI Flexibility ‚Äì Creating an Embedded Section

     


     

  2. Rearrange sections with UI Flexibility (drag and drop)

     

 

Conclusion

UI Flexibility in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT bridges the gap between business agility and technical governance.
It empowers key users to personalize their workspace, bring in the data and tools they need, and keep pace with changing business processes ‚Äî all while IT retains control of the underlying architecture.

In short:

You don‚Äôt need to be a developer to make SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT work smarter ‚Äî just flexible.

entry.title: Re: Introducing Application Vulnerability Report for Cloudfoundry Applications ‚Äì Try It Now!
entry.content:
Hi @MatthiasL,

Thank you for your feedback! As for your questions, please find the answers below:

1) When you go to the main help page and click What's New you get no results. However going there via other link (via) does yield results

The "Whats New" section in our product documentation contains changes to the product itself, the other "Whats New" section is part of the overall BTP documentation which also mentions new services / products. We will definitely use that section when we add new features to the product itself.

2) Since it's in beta, you need to enable the beta feature for said subaccount. I feel like this should be clarified more, both from a perspective of how to activate it - but also because I get a warning when turning it on to not use it in production and that I can't disable it. So not sure if I should turn it on, even for our R&D subaccount.

We understand that concern. If you want to separate beta applications from your main R&D subaccount, you can also create a dedicated subaccount with access to beta features. By adding our technical user to other spaces, you can still scan them even if the service is subscribed in a different subaccount, as long as the subaccount which should be scanned is in one of the following data centers: cf-eu10 (including extension landscapes), cf-22 and cf-eu30. For security and compliance reasons, we can only scan in the same region the scanner resides in.

3) Still can't find it in the Discovery pages, while it is mentioned that it should be. Also, another dead link under "See Always Free Tag"

We are actively working on that.

4) It could be a bit more specific about what kind of 0 days and BTP specific things it detects (from)

During the beta, the scanner will only scan using the osv-scanner, when we add additional scanners we will explicitly state information about them in our documentation.

5) When clicking the Info button from BTP to the product, it brings you to another dead URL

Thank you for noticing, we are working on fixing that!

6) When searching for Vulnerability in help.sap you don't find anything, when searching for application vulnerability you sort of find it - but neither of them are listed as products (perhaps because it's in beta?)

We will have a look, it might take some time for help.sap.com to index new resources.

Best Regards,
Henry

entry.title: Re: #CoE#MRAS Volume test for public cloud
entry.content:
Dear @ericyu,

In Public Cloud you usually don‚Äôt need classic infrastructure sizing trying to find the breaking point of the platform, because SAP owns the runtime and does performance testing on their side and they don‚Äôt generally publish tenant-level benchmark results but you often still should do a volume test just with a different goal, prove that your business processes, integrations, and data volumes work within your peak periods and time windows (month-end, MRP, mass jobs etc.)

Do it if you have any of these risk factors:

  • High transactional volumes (orders, deliveries, invoices, warehouse postings, journal entries, etc.)
  • Tight batch windows (jobs, MRP, settlement, dunning, EOM close)
  • Many/critical integrations (BTP, EDI, external tax, banks, e-commerce) where throughput/queues matter
  • Significant data migration volume and you need confidence that reporting and processing times stay acceptable
  • Custom extensions / custom analytics
  • Business peak simulation run the top 10‚Äì20 critical processes at expected peak
  • Integration throughput test burst messages at realistic peak rates and validate queues, retries, end-to-end completion times
  • Period-end rehearsal close steps that must finish in a window (FI close tasks, MRP runs, etc.).
  • Data-volume realism test with production-like master/transaction data

To get production like data in your Quality system, SAP offers Test Data Refresh copying master and transactional data from Production to Quality, configuration isn‚Äôt copied and integrations must be validated afterward

More details below:

https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/s4hana-cloud-test-data-refresh/faq

How to execute it safely:

  1. Monitor and document issues, use an ALM/monitoring layer SAP Cloud ALM is designed to help monitor the landscape, including extensions
  2. Prepare realistic data migration rehearsal loads or Test Data Refresh
  3. Run focused scenarios, measure response times + end-to-end completion including interfaces

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Why You Cannot Create Clients in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (and Why It Still Matters)
entry.content:
One common question many SAP professionals ask when they start working with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is:

‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt I create a client using SCC4, like we do in on-premise or private cloud systems?‚Äù

It feels unusual for anyone who has worked with SAP systems before 2020, because the client is one of the most fundamental concepts in classic SAP landscapes.

Let‚Äôs explore why this difference exists, what problem it solves, and how the public cloud handles ‚Äúmultiple environments‚Äù without clients.

 1. What is a Client in On-Premise SAP?

In SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, a client is an isolated logical environment inside one SAP system.

  1. It has its own master data

  2. It has its own users

  3. It has its own configuration

  4. It does not share application data with other clients

This separation allowed companies to create:

  1. A development client

  2. A testing client

  3. A training client

  4. A production client

All inside the same SAP system.

To manage these clients, SAP uses transaction SCC4.

 2. Why Clients Still Exist in Private Cloud

S/4HANA Private Cloud (RISE with SAP) is technically similar to on-premise.
Companies have full control over configuration and can design their own landscape.

So, they may still use multiple clients for:

  1. Development

  2. Testing

  3. Integration

  4. Training

  5. Production

And yes, SCC4 is still available, depending on the model and access rights.

 3. Why Clients Do Not Exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud has a different design philosophy:

  1. Standardization over customization

  2. Automation over manual setup

  3. Security by default

  4. Faster implementation and upgrades

Because of this, SAP does not allow customers to:

  1. Create clients manually

  2. Configure technical landscapes

  3. Define transport routes

So, SCC4 is not available to the customer.

This is not a limitation‚Äîit is a strategic decision by SAP.

 4. How Public Cloud Replaces Clients

Instead of clients, Public Cloud uses separate tenants managed by SAP:

  1. Starter system

  2. Customize system 
  3. Development system 
  4. Test tenant
  5. Production System 

Different activities are separated through:

  • CBC (Configuration, Business Process Content)

  • SAP Central Business Configuration Projects

  • Task lists and scoping

  • Automated transports

This ensures configuration is:

  • Consistent

  • Auditable

  • Upgrade-stable

And aligned with SAP best practices.

 5. Why SAP Removed Client Creation

Allowing customers to create their own clients would make:

  • Upgrade cycles slower

  • Systems harder to secure

  • Business processes inconsistent

  • Total cost of ownership higher

SAP wants Public Cloud to be:

  • Always up-to-date

  • Predictable

  • Safe

  • Configurable, not customizable

Which is only possible if the base architecture stays controlled.

 6. The Big Idea

The difference reflects a massive shift:

On-Premise /  Private Cloud                          Public Cloud
Build your systemConsume best practices
Full technical controlGuided configuration
Multiple clientsMultiple SAP-managed tenants
Slow upgrades

Automatic quarterly upgrades

Public Cloud is not about ‚Äúdoing everything yourself‚Äù.
It is about running a modern ERP with less effort and more reliability.

 Final Thought

You cannot create clients in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud not because SAP removed a feature, but because SAP redesigned the entire deployment model to focus on:

  1. Standardization
  2. Speed
  3. Quality
  4. Security

And the outcome is a system that is simpler to operate and faster to innovate.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Causes for ‚ÄúAccrual Item Obsolete‚Äù a...
entry.content:
Good day @rohini_dutta21 

Thank you for your question.

1. Answers to ‚ÄúAccrual Item is Obsolete‚Äù:

  • Yes, your understanding is correct. The system automatically sets any linked accrual object to Obsolete if a PO item is marked to be deleted. I have not seen any workaround for this. So it suggests a hardcoded behaviour.
  • No, I don‚Äôt think so. I have only encountered that with PO deletion. Final Invoices, clearing of GR or manual accrual releases has not caused such scenarios for me.

--> My advice is to ensure that you have completed all necessary posting before you mark a PO item for deletion. This will ensure you avoid complications with the associated accrual item.

--> You may also consider reviewing the lifecycle of your accrual items regularly, to ensure their statuses still meet your business requirements.

2. Answer to Accrual Subobject Status: ‚ÄúPrematurely Finished‚Äù

 Yes, I have experienced a few event-based accrual status changes. Some of them are:

  • When Goods Receipt and Invoice match. In this case the systems considered the PO lifecycle as complete.
  • When my accrual amount reaches zero. Logically, the system understands there are no remaining balance and therefore closes the object.
  • An automatic accrual method was used and the system closed it based on the rule logic
  • Even when entire accrual amount has been posted, the subobject can be marked Prematurely Finished, even if the PO itself remained open.

Here are some supporting documentations:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/92328b3f8d0141f3a3ad4df8e3fc2ca2.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2a560f6f15704c50a261627bb4691fbc/456bafaf76c04b90a17ae8aa94f5a930.html?locale=en-US

On your question about background logic:

Yes, the accrual engine contains some background jobs that process subobjects and evaluate closure criterias like detecting when GR/IR balances are cleared, automatically closing subobjects when you mark them as completed or may act based on how you configure it.

This Blog provides some good insights: Modifying posting information in the Purchase Order Accruals Process ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Settlement Periods for Service Contract items are blank
entry.content:
Why Settlement Periods are not displayed because, Settlement periods are generated only if:

  • A Settlement Rule is defined in the Service Contract item.
  • A Settlement Schedule (periodicity, e.g. monthly/quarterly/yearly) is assigned.
  • The contract item is marked as Relevant for Settlement.

Simply entering start/end dates defines the validity of the contract but does not trigger period creation.

Check the following:

In the Service Contract item, ensure a settlement rule exists (e.g., revenue recognition rule). Without this, no settlement periods are created.

Define the periodicity (monthly, quarterly, annually) in the item. This tells the system how to break down the contract duration into settlement periods.

Verify that the item category used is settlement‚Äërelevant. Some item categories are purely informational and won‚Äôt generate settlement periods.

entry.title: F110 : payment not possible because of reported error
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We have created a new company code in SAP, and the configuration appears to be complete. Nothing seems to be missing in the FBZP setup.

However, I am unable to process any payments using F110. The system returns the message ‚ÄúPayment not possible because of reported error‚Äù without indicating which error it refers to.

entry.title: Re: December VAT return not visible in Run Statutory Repo...
entry.content:
Likely root causes are December may not have been created or opened in statutory reporting configuration. December overlaps with fiscal year-end. If the year is not closed or carried forward, the period may not appear. If no transactions exist in December, the system may not generate a return.

Check this SAP Help What's New  and SAP note 2480067

entry.title: Visualizing License Metric History in Customer Insights Dashboard
entry.content:
Gaining visibility into your license utilization is essential for maximizing the value of your SAP investments. The Customer Insights Dashboard (CID) in SAP for Me includes a robust License Consumption insights features designed to provide deep insights into your usage. In this article, we‚Äôll cover the new enhancement capabilities with Metric History sub-section and demonstrate the benefits organizations can achieve by utilizing these analytics.

 

What is Metric History?

Metric History delivers a comprehensive perspective on license consumption trends for individual metrics over time. Rather than just presenting a point-in-time snapshot, this feature tracks various metrics‚Äîsuch as user numbers, API consumption, or storage‚Äîenabling you to observe how your usage develops. Within the dashboard, you can monitor activity by the number of metrics, as well as visualize historical usage for each one. With introduction of this new "Metric History" sub-section we renamed previously called "History" sub-section (described in this blog) to "Overall History".

 

How to Visualize Your Data

Metric History offers flexible visualization options. To see the history for a specific Metric ID, simply select the desired row in the Current Consumption Details table. For example, to review how Metric ID CH 12 "Users - Planning professional public edition" has changed over the past 12 months, just click on that row to generate a corresponding chart.

By clicking on hyperlinked Metric ID (such as CH12) detailed documentation is opened for license metric object in a new browser tab.

Analyses can be refined by filtering‚Äîby Metric ID, Consumption Intensity (like Over Consumption >100%, Low Consumption <20%, or Regular Consumption 20%-100%), or by adjusting the chart‚Äôs time range from the default period of 12 months.

If you prefer for your analysis to view metrics grouped by Solution Area, you can enable grouping. This helps identify where there may be over-consumption risks or unused subscriptions within specific solution areas.

Dashboard also lets you switch between different chart formats, such as moving from a line graph to a stacked column chart, to best visualize your data.

 

Key Advantages of Metric History

  • Actionable Consumption Insights: Instantly see where you might be nearing license thresholds, exceeding allocations, or underutilizing assets across products and solutions.
  • Informed Decision Making: Identify trends to guide future subscription planning, support informed negotiations during renewals, and maintain compliance based on real usage data.
  • Detailed Drill-Down Capabilities: Conduct in-depth analysis by product type, solution area, or individual metric for targeted, actionable insights.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: Easily communicate findings with internal teams, SAP support, and SAP front office teams‚Äîensuring alignment.
  • Customizable Visualizations: Leverage flexible options like adjustable history timelines, metric filters, and various visualization types to tailor reporting to your needs.

 

Stay updated by subscribing to this blog and visiting the SAP Support Portal / Customer Insights.

SAP for Me is made for you!

 

Related blogs: License consumption in Customer Insights, License Consumption History in Customer Insights Dashboard or all related blogs to ‚ÄòCustomer Insights‚Äô reporting dashboard.

entry.title: Re: Manage group to team assignments for SAC within Ident...
entry.content:
Hi @dyaryura ,

thanks for the screenshots - that helped a lot. And now it si working on our side as well.

Just as a remark, if you follow the SAP Help on adding a bundled Cloud Identity Service tenant to SAC the application in the Cloud Identity Service tenant is created using OIDC.

However, even if the application is created using OIDC the rest of the configuration is the same. Meaning, we created an attribute "custom1" and mapped it to "All Groups" within the Cloud Identity Services

Then we edited the "SAML Team Mapping" in the SAC for the corresponding teams. Just we used the (technical) name of the group in Cloud Identity Service rather the "group ID" as in you case.

So, SAML attribute mapping is also working even if the Cloud Identity Service tenant is connected via OIDC to the SAC.

entry.title: Why FinTech Companies Fail at Execution: The Hidden Gaps in Strategy Mapping and How to Fix Them
entry.content:
FinTechs rarely fail because the idea was weak. They fail because execution was never wired to the idea in the first place.
And that failure shows itself long before any KPI moves in the wrong direction.
It appears in the architecture, in the way teams interpret priorities, and in how strategy gets translated into decisions.

This article unpacks the blind spots that quietly derail FinTech execution and offers a precise method to rebuild strategic clarity before scale exposes the fractures.

The First Gap: A Strategy That Doesn‚Äôt Anchor to Capabilities

Every FinTech strategy depends on a handful of critical capabilities:
risk intelligence, real-time financial decisioning, embedded experience orchestration, onboarding throughput, data lineage, and automated compliance.

When the capability map is missing, incomplete, or purely decorative, the strategy becomes unmoored.
Teams move with speed, but the speed has no architecture underneath it. Products grow horizontally rather than structurally.
What looks like innovation is often just entropy with a nice UI. Executives catch the symptoms:

  • growing operational friction
  • inconsistent product decisions
  • dependency explosion
  • opaque ownership lines
  • roadmap volatility

The actual cause sits higher: strategy was never grounded in capability reality.

The Second Gap: A Fragmented Operating Model That Breaks Under Growth

FinTechs scale asymmetrically. Risk grows faster than revenue.
Compliance grows faster than engineering. Customer touchpoints proliferate faster than data governance.

When these growth vectors aren‚Äôt mapped, the operating model collapses into firefighting.
Customer acquisition accelerates, but onboarding becomes the bottleneck.
Feature deployment accelerates, but incident response becomes the bottleneck.
Partnerships expand, but data exchange maturity doesn‚Äôt.

If the operating model isn‚Äôt engineered to scale in a sequence that matches strategic priorities, execution will break, no matter how talented the team is.

The Third Gap: Strategy Mapping Used as Decoration, Not Navigation

Most FinTech strategy maps fall into one of three traps:

  1. They‚Äôre too high-level. Vision without operational binding.
  2. They‚Äôre too abstract. Attractive graphics with no execution semantics.
  3. They‚Äôre too static. Built once a year, untouched for eleven months.

An effective strategy map isn‚Äôt a diagram. It‚Äôs a navigation system that binds:

  • strategic intent
  • capability impact
  • process consequences
  • data implications
  • organizational roles
  • investment priorities
  • compliance exposure

When done well, you can trace any feature, risk, or change request back to the strategic objective it serves.
Most FinTechs can‚Äôt do this. And that‚Äôs the real execution gap.

How to Actually Fix the Execution Gap
Step 1: Rebuild Your Strategy Map with Execution Semantics

Stop building for aesthetics. Start building for traceability. Every objective should link to capabilities, metrics, and constraints.

Step 2: Construct a Capability Model That Reflects Future FinTech Reality

Your capability map must already consider:

  • algorithmic risk scoring
  • embedded finance orchestration
  • automated compliance intelligence
  • cross-border identity services
  • intelligent liquidity flows

Capability models shouldn‚Äôt reflect your company today; They should reflect the enterprise you intend to become.

Step 3: Redesign the Operating Model for Asymmetric Scale

Map the sequence in which each layer is expected to grow. Then align hiring, investment, partnerships, and technology evolution to that sequence. This single move eliminates 70 percent of execution gaps.

Step 4: Create Bidirectional Traceability from Strategy to Decisions

Every backlog item, every change, every quarter‚Äôs OKRs should map upward to the strategy map and back downward into the capability stack. FinTech execution becomes consistent only when this loop becomes unbreakable.

FinTechs rarely suffer from a lack of vision. They suffer from a lack of structural clarity. The market rewards speed, but it punishes incoherence. Strategy mapping, when elevated from a diagram to an operating system, is the crucial mechanism that keeps speed from turning into chaos.

Execution isn‚Äôt a matter of effort.
Execution is a matter of architecture.

entry.title: Re: Supplier Contract for multiple Company Codes
entry.content:
Hello Kathrin,

 

in S4H public Cloud it is possible create a Reference Purchasing Org. and assign multiple Purchasing Organisations, even from other countries.

When you create the purchasing contract you still have to enter one company code and purchasing org. -> here you enter the reference purchasing org.

Then you enter the items and let the plant empty.

Now you can assign this purchasing contract to all Purchasing organisations which are maintained for the reference Org.
